Creatine is an organic acid that is synthesized in the liver, kidneys, and pancreas from the amino acids glycine, arginine, and methionine. It is primarily stored in skeletal muscles, where it serves as a readily available energy source for high-intensity physical activities.

During muscle contraction, ATP is rapidly broken down to release energy. However, the ATP stores in the muscle are limited, and it can take some time to resynthesize ATP from other sources. This can lead to fatigue and decreased performance.

Creatine supplementation increases the amount of stored creatine in muscle fibers, which can help to replenish ATP stores more quickly during high-intensity activities. Creatine serves as a phosphate donor for the resynthesis of ATP from ADP (adenosine diphosphate) via the creatine kinase reaction. This reaction is reversible and allows for rapid ATP regeneration during intense exercise.

In addition to its role in energy metabolism, creatine has been shown to have other physiological effects, such as increasing muscle protein synthesis, reducing muscle damage and inflammation, and improving cognitive function.

Overall, creatine supplementation has been found to enhance athletic performance in activities that require short bursts of intense effort, such as weightlifting, sprinting, and jumping.
